attributes.title: THE PREDICTIVE ROLE OF CIRCUMCISION AGE ON SEXUAL EXPERIENCES OF MEN WHO LIVE IN TURKEY: MEDIATOR ROLE OF SELF RELATED CONCEPTS
attributes.description: In the light of the literature, this study is aimed to investigate the predictive role of circumcision age on erectile disorder and/or premature ejaculation symptoms and overall sexual satisfaction by measuring mediator role of self-esteem and self-efficacy in this prediction. It is expected that circumcision age predicts both self-esteem and self-efficacy negatively and this mediator role have an effect on male sexual experiences in terms of premature ejaculation, erectile disorders and sexual satisfaction. These expected relationships are shown in figure 1. At the end of the research, it is expected to find erectile disorder and premature ejaculation will show changes according to circumcision age. Sexual dysfunction symptoms will increase, and sexual satisfaction will decrease according to age with the effects of the mediators. To be clearer, as the age increases, sexual dysfunction symptoms will also increase, and sexual satisfaction will decrease.

q1.value: The Predictive Role of Circumcision Age on Sexual Experiences of Men Who Live in Turkey: Mediating Role of Self-Related Concepts

q3.value: In the light of the literature, this study is aimed to investigate the predictive role of circumcision age on erectile disorder and/or premature ejaculation symptoms and overall sexual satisfaction by measuring mediator role of self-esteem and self-efficacy in this prediction. It is expected that circumcision age predicts both self-esteem and self-efficacy negatively and this mediator role have an effect on male sexual experiences in terms of premature ejaculation, erectile disorders and sexual satisfaction. At the end of the research, it is expected to find erectile disorder and premature ejaculation will show changes according to circumcision age. Sexual dysfunction symptoms will increase, and sexual satisfaction will decrease according to age with the effects of the mediators. To be clearer, as the age increases, sexual dysfunction symptoms will also increase, and sexual satisfaction will decrease.

q4.value:
1.	According to the model of the study, self-related concepts (self-esteem and self-efficacy) will play mediating role between circumcision age and sexual experiences of participants (premature ejaculation, erectile disorder and sexual satisfaction). Therefore, it is expected that circumcision age and self-related concepts will have a negative relationship. While self-related concepts will have negative relationship with sexual dysfunction symptoms (premature ejaculation and erectile disorder), they will have positive relationship with sexual satisfaction. 
2.	It is also expected that there will be a significant difference among groups of circumcision age in terms of the relationship status, duration of the relationship and current age of participants.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with factorial measures in order to create a model.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Firstly, informed consent for study will be provided to participants. Participation to this study will be voluntary. After participants approve informed consent, demographic information form, The Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), The Golombok-Rust Inventory of Sexual Satisfaction (GRISS) and Two-Dimensional Self-Esteem: The Self-Liking/Self-Competence Scale (SLCS) will be distributed to participants respectively. This research will be announced via social media and all measurement tools will be distributed to participants via online forms (such as Google Forms). If it possible, measurement instruments may be distributed by personally without using social media. All measurement instruments will be distributed randomly. After participants fill all instrument, firstly the perceived stress scale form will be evaluated and if it is determined that participants will have higher acute stress level, these participants will be excluded from the study to prevent effect of acute stress on sexual dysfunctions. After this process, other instruments will be evaluated, and scores of participants will be determined.

q13.value: 290 circumcised male whose age range change between 18 and 50 will be involved in this present study to answer research questions.

question.value:
Circumcision age
Premature Ejaculation
Erectile Disorder
Sexual Satisfaction
Self-esteem and Self-efficacy

In order to answer all research questions, path analysis and all statistical analysis will be done by using IBM Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS)/AMOS program so that models of the study will be formed. Also, IBM SPSS 22 version will be used in order to compare age groups with one-way Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA).

q22.value: If the subject has a current psychiatric diagnosis or using any prescribed drugs regarding psychiatrics disorders, and participants who have high stress level according to measurement will be excluded from the study.

q23.value: If any questions are left unaswered in the measurements, the data of the subject will not be included.

attributes.title: THE RELATIONSHIP OF ADULT ATTACHMENT STYLES, RELATIONSHIP SATISFACTION, AND INTENTION OF INFIDELITY WITH RELATIONSHIP-CENTERED AND PARTNER-FOCUSED OBSESSIVE-COMPULSIVE SYMPTOMS

q1.value: THE RELATIONSHIP OF ADULT ATTACHMENT STYLES, RELATIONSHIP SATISFACTION, AND INTENTION OF INFIDELITY WITH RELATIONSHIP-CENTERED AND PARTNER-FOCUSED OBSESSIVE-COMPULSIVE SYMPTOMS

q3.value:
The aim of the present study is to investigate the roles of adult attachment styles, relationship satisfaction, and intention of infidelity on relationship-centered and partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Based on the model of the present study, detailed aims of the study are:
1)	To investigate the differences of adult attachment styles on the variables of the study,
2)	To explore the differences of gender on the measures of the study, 
3)	To examine the effects of relationship satisfaction on two subtypes of ROCD symptoms which are relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms and partner-focused obsessive compulsive symptoms. 
4)	To examine the effects of intention of infidelity on two subtypes of ROCD symptoms which are relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms and partner-focused obsessive compulsive symptoms.
5)	To examine the correlation between relationship satisfaction and infidelity.

Relationship Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder is a variation of obsessive-compulsive disorder and it is relatively new to the literature. Thus, literature about ROCD is lack of different studies to understand its relationship with different variables. Since ROCD is concerned with romantic relationships; adult attachment styles, intentions of infidelity and relationship satisfaction are closely related to the topic and their contributions to each other will bring a new aspect and vision to the understanding of the concept. Especially, intention of infidelity is not a well inspected topic and its relationship with two different dimensions of ROCD symptoms would provide a new awareness regarding the aspects. More importantly, there are only a few studies of ROCD conducted on a Turkish population and this study will benefit the literature by inspecting ROCD’s relationship with other variables on a different population. Moreover, in clinical applications regarding OCD, unique nature of ROCD is not yet introduced in Turkey, and this study will contribute to the assessment and applications by providing more information about the topic.

q4.value:
1.	There will be differences in terms of relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms between two genders.
2.	Intention of infidelity will be a mediator between anxious/avoidant attachment styles and relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Higher levels of anxious/avoidant attachment will result in higher levels of intention of infidelity and higher levels of intention of infidelity will result in an increase in the levels of relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
3.	Intention of infidelity will be a mediator between anxious/avoidant attachment style and partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Higher levels of anxious/avoidant attachment will result in higher levels of intention of infidelity and higher levels of intention of infidelity will result in an increase in the levels of partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
4.	Relationship satisfaction will be a mediator between anxious/avoidant attachment style and relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Lower levels of relationship satisfaction will result in lower levels of relationship satisfaction and lower levels of relationship satisfaction will result in an increase in the levels of relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
5.	Relationship satisfaction will be a mediator between anxious/avoidant attachment style and partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Lower levels of relationship satisfaction will result in lower levels of relationship satisfaction and lower levels of relationship satisfaction will result in an increase in the levels of partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
6.	Relationship satisfaction and intention of infidelity will simultaneously and consecutively mediate the relationship between anxious/avoidant attachment and relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms. According to this, higher levels of anxious/avoidant attachment will result in an decrease in the levels of relationship satisfaction, and lower relationship satisfaction will correlate with an increase in the levels intention of infidelity, and this increase in the levels of intention of infidelity will result in an increase in the levels of relationship-centered obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
7.	Relationship satisfaction and intention of infidelity will simultaneously and consecutively mediate the relationship between anxious/avoidant attachment and partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms. According to this, higher levels of anxious/avoidant attachment will result in an decrease in the levels of relationship satisfaction, and lower relationship satisfaction will correlate with an increase in the levels of intention of infidelity, and this increase in the levels of intention of infidelity will result in an increase in the levels of partner-focused obsessive-compulsive symptoms.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with factorial measures in order to create a model.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: In order to proceed to data gathering process, ethical approval will be received from Başkent University Scientific Research and Publication Ethics Committee. For data gathering, participants will be recruited from Internet via Qualtrics and if possible, the forms will be delivered to participants by hand. Participation to the study will be voluntary. In the beginning of the procedure, participants will be asked to read and sign off the informed consent. After participants confirm to be included in the study, they will be given Demographic Information Form. Subsequently, following instruments will be presented to the participants for them to fill out: Relationship Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory, Partner-Related Obsessive-Compulsive Symptom Inventory, Relationship Assessment Inventory, Experiences in Close Relationships-Revised Scale, and The Intentions Toward Infidelity Scale, respectively. After completion of all scales, participants with a psychiatric diagnose and/or drug use will be excluded from the study in order to prevent the effect of a diagnose or drug use on the results. Participants who fail to complete any questions of any forms will also be excluded. After the exclusion process, all instruments will be evaluated to determine the scores of participants for each given variable.

q13.value: The sample of the current study will include 300 participants. Of these 300 participants, 150 (50%) of the sample will be females and 150 (50%) will be males. The ages of the participants will be ranged from 18 to 65.

question.value:
Adult Attachments Styles,
Relationship Satisfaction,
Intention of Infidelity,
Relationship-centered Obsessive-Compulsive Symptoms
Partner-focused Obsessive-compulsive Symptoms

All statistical analyses will be conducted by using IBM Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 22.0 for Windows. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) will be carried out to investigate the difference contributed by age, gender, and relationship duration on each measure of the current study. Moreover, several multiple regression analyses will be conducted to demonstrate the related aspects of relationship centered obsessive compulsive symptoms, and partner focused obsessive compulsive symptoms. Additionally, path analysis will be conducted via SPSS/AMOS in order to form the model of the study.

q22.value: If the subject has a current psychiatric diagnosis or using any prescribed drugs regarding psychiatrics disorders, they will be excluded.

q23.value: If any questions are left unaswered in the measurements, the data of the subject will be excluded.

attributes.title: Effects of Genistein for Glycolipid Metabolism in Postmenopausal Women

q1.value: Effects of genistein for glycolipid metabolism in postmenopausal women

q2.value: Xiao-yan Yi, Yao Wang, Zhi-hong Wang

q3.value: Due to the decrease of estrogens, risk for cardiovascular diseases in postmenopausal women increases. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is effective for relieving clinical symptoms such as hot flushes, but researchers found that HRT could increase risks for cardiovascular diseases, breast cancer, endometrial cancer and thromboembolic events. Genistein, a phytoestrogen with selective estrogen receptor modulator properties, is effective in reducing cardiovascular risk factors. However, the results are controversial. Then, we design a meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of genistein in glycolipid metabolism in postmenopausal women.

q4.value: Genistein is effective in lowering lipid profiles and improving insulin resistance in postmenopausal women.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
METHODS
Criteria for included studies
Types of studies
We include only randomized controlled trials (RCTs). We will only consider the results from the first randomization period when with a crossover design. Quasi-randomized trials (e.g., sequence based on date or day of admission) will be excluded. 
Types of participants
We will include postmenopausal women, excluding those with surgically induced menopause. Trials where both naturally menopausal and surgically menopausal will be eligible for inclusion, if data on the naturally menopausal can be extracted separately, or obtained from trial authors. Postmenopausal women are characterized as menstrual cessation for at least 12 months prior to intervention. They can have dyslipidemia, impaired glucose tolerance, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and metabolic syndrome, or not. Participants taking hormones or lipid-lowering agents will be excluded.
Types of interventions
RCTs comparing the effects of genistein with placebo will be included. Genistein is administered as an isolated active treatment, and not a composition of treatment (such as a soy diet, isoflavone mixtures) or a combination of treatment (such as genistein and probiotics). The comparison can only be inactive placebo. Supplement of the same dose of calcium and vitamin D, and equivalent exercises in both groups, will be allowed. Hormone replacement therapy is administered in neither group. 
Types of outcome measures
1.The primary outcomes
  The primary outcome for lipid metabolism will be mean overall changed value of low density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) from baseline to the end-point, and for glucose metabolism will be mean overall changed value of homeostasis model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) from baseline to the end-point. HOMA-IR=fasting insulin (µIU/mL)*fating blood glucose (mg/dl)/22.5. 
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of total cholesterol (TC), triglyceride (TG), high density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), fasting blood glucose (FBG), fasting blood insulin (INS) and body mass index (BMI) from baseline to the end-point.

Search strategy
All published, unpublished, and ongoing randomized controlled trials that comparing genistein with placebo in the treatment of postmenopausal women will be included. We will identify relevant trials from systematic searches in the following electronic databases; PubMed, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, and Web of Science. We will also hand-search reference lists of trials identified in the initial searches and relevant review papers. The search deadline will be from inception to March 2020. There will be no restrictions on language, publication year, or publication type. The following keywords will be used: menopaus*, postmenopaus*, climacteric, genistein. In addition, all relevant authors will be contacted to supplement incomplete information.

Study selection and data extraction
Selection of trials
Titles and abstracts identified from the search strategies will be independently examined by two reviewers (XYY and YW). If both reviewers judge that the trial does not meet eligibility criteria, we will exclude it. Then, we will obtain the full-texts of all remaining articles and determine whether to include them by the same eligibility criteria. Any disagreements were resolved by a third review author (ZHW). Besides, the references of relevant reviews and included trials will also be checked by XYY and YW. The reasons for exclusion of trials will be reported in the characteristics of excluded studies tables.
Quality assessment
The methodological quality of the included studies will be independently assessed by two reviewers (XYY and YW). We will assess risk of bias as “low risk”, “unclear risk”, or “high risk”, in accordance with the Cochrane Collaboration’s ‘Risk of bias’ tool as described in the Cochrane Hand book for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Any disagreements were resolved by a third review author (ZHW).
Data extraction
Two independent reviewers (XYY and YW) will extract the data from the original reports using standardized data extraction forms, including of study characteristics (such as first listed author, publication year, journal, country, and institution), patient characteristics (such as the number of patients, and patients’ baseline), intervention details (such as the duration and dosage of treatment) and outcome measures. Any disagreements will be resolved by a third review author (ZHW).

Statistical analysis
All analyses were performed using RevMan 5.3 software (Cochrane Information Management System). Efficacy was evaluated by change values from baseline to end point data on each outcomes in this meta-analysis. When standard error (SD) was missing in an article and could not contact the authors, it would be calculated from reported P values, t values, confidence intervals (CIs) or standard errors (SEs). A random-effects model was applied in this meta-analysis in order to get relatively robust results. Standardized mean differences (SMD) in continuous measure, as well as 95% CIs, were estimated by inverse variance models. Heterogeneity was evaluated with the test of inconsistency. It represented large, moderate and small heterogeneity when I2 statistic was higher than 75%, 50% and 25%, respectively. And we used subgroup analyses and sensitivity analyses to find possible sources of the heterogeneity. The publication bias was assessed by Egger tests (Stata 13.0, Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). A two-sided P value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant if not specifically stated. 
Subgroup analysis
Where possible, the following subgroups analysis will be performed: (i) for the BMI of participants (e.g. BMI≧30 vs. <30); (ii) for the dosage of genistein (e.g. dosage<54mg/d vs. ≧54mg/d); (iii) for the duration of genistein (e.g. duration≦1 year vs. >1 year); (iv) for diet (e.g. restricted or not); (v) physical condition (e.g. healthy vs. metabolic diseases); (vi) for enrollment sites (e.g. single centre vs. multi-centres).
Sensitivity analyses

registration_responses.q1: Effects of genistein for glycolipid metabolism in postmenopausal women
registration_responses.q2: Xiao-yan Yi, Yao Wang, Zhi-hong Wang
registration_responses.q3: Due to the decrease of estrogens, risk for cardiovascular diseases in postmenopausal women increases. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is effective for relieving clinical symptoms such as hot flushes, but researchers found that HRT could increase risks for cardiovascular diseases, breast cancer, endometrial cancer and thromboembolic events. Genistein, a phytoestrogen with selective estrogen receptor modulator properties, is effective in reducing cardiovascular risk factors. However, the results are controversial. Then, we design a meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of genistein in glycolipid metabolism in postmenopausal women.
registration_responses.q4: Genistein is effective in lowering lipid profiles and improving insulin resistance in postmenopausal women.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
METHODS
Criteria for included studies
Types of studies
We include only randomized controlled trials (RCTs). We will only consider the results from the first randomization period when with a crossover design. Quasi-randomized trials (e.g., sequence based on date or day of admission) will be excluded. 
Types of participants
We will include postmenopausal women, excluding those with surgically induced menopause. Trials where both naturally menopausal and surgically menopausal will be eligible for inclusion, if data on the naturally menopausal can be extracted separately, or obtained from trial authors. Postmenopausal women are characterized as menstrual cessation for at least 12 months prior to intervention. They can have dyslipidemia, impaired glucose tolerance, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and metabolic syndrome, or not. Participants taking hormones or lipid-lowering agents will be excluded.
Types of interventions
RCTs comparing the effects of genistein with placebo will be included. Genistein is administered as an isolated active treatment, and not a composition of treatment (such as a soy diet, isoflavone mixtures) or a combination of treatment (such as genistein and probiotics). The comparison can only be inactive placebo. Supplement of the same dose of calcium and vitamin D, and equivalent exercises in both groups, will be allowed. Hormone replacement therapy is administered in neither group. 
Types of outcome measures
1.The primary outcomes
  The primary outcome for lipid metabolism will be mean overall changed value of low density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) from baseline to the end-point, and for glucose metabolism will be mean overall changed value of homeostasis model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) from baseline to the end-point. HOMA-IR=fasting insulin (µIU/mL)*fating blood glucose (mg/dl)/22.5. 
2.The secondary outcomes　
The secondary outcomes will be mean overall changed value of total cholesterol (TC), triglyceride (TG), high density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), fasting blood glucose (FBG), fasting blood insulin (INS) and body mass index (BMI) from baseline to the end-point.

Search strategy
All published, unpublished, and ongoing randomized controlled trials that comparing genistein with placebo in the treatment of postmenopausal women will be included. We will identify relevant trials from systematic searches in the following electronic databases; PubMed, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, and Web of Science. We will also hand-search reference lists of trials identified in the initial searches and relevant review papers. The search deadline will be from inception to March 2020. There will be no restrictions on language, publication year, or publication type. The following keywords will be used: menopaus*, postmenopaus*, climacteric, genistein. In addition, all relevant authors will be contacted to supplement incomplete information.

Study selection and data extraction
Selection of trials
Titles and abstracts identified from the search strategies will be independently examined by two reviewers (XYY and YW). If both reviewers judge that the trial does not meet eligibility criteria, we will exclude it. Then, we will obtain the full-texts of all remaining articles and determine whether to include them by the same eligibility criteria. Any disagreements were resolved by a third review author (ZHW). Besides, the references of relevant reviews and included trials will also be checked by XYY and YW. The reasons for exclusion of trials will be reported in the characteristics of excluded studies tables.
Quality assessment
The methodological quality of the included studies will be independently assessed by two reviewers (XYY and YW). We will assess risk of bias as “low risk”, “unclear risk”, or “high risk”, in accordance with the Cochrane Collaboration’s ‘Risk of bias’ tool as described in the Cochrane Hand book for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Any disagreements were resolved by a third review author (ZHW).
Data extraction
Two independent reviewers (XYY and YW) will extract the data from the original reports using standardized data extraction forms, including of study characteristics (such as first listed author, publication year, journal, country, and institution), patient characteristics (such as the number of patients, and patients’ baseline), intervention details (such as the duration and dosage of treatment) and outcome measures. Any disagreements will be resolved by a third review author (ZHW).

Statistical analysis
All analyses were performed using RevMan 5.3 software (Cochrane Information Management System). Efficacy was evaluated by change values from baseline to end point data on each outcomes in this meta-analysis. When standard error (SD) was missing in an article and could not contact the authors, it would be calculated from reported P values, t values, confidence intervals (CIs) or standard errors (SEs). A random-effects model was applied in this meta-analysis in order to get relatively robust results. Standardized mean differences (SMD) in continuous measure, as well as 95% CIs, were estimated by inverse variance models. Heterogeneity was evaluated with the test of inconsistency. It represented large, moderate and small heterogeneity when I2 statistic was higher than 75%, 50% and 25%, respectively. And we used subgroup analyses and sensitivity analyses to find possible sources of the heterogeneity. The publication bias was assessed by Egger tests (Stata 13.0, Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). A two-sided P value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant if not specifically stated. 
Subgroup analysis
Where possible, the following subgroups analysis will be performed: (i) for the BMI of participants (e.g. BMI≧30 vs. <30); (ii) for the dosage of genistein (e.g. dosage<54mg/d vs. ≧54mg/d); (iii) for the duration of genistein (e.g. duration≦1 year vs. >1 year); (iv) for diet (e.g. restricted or not); (v) physical condition (e.g. healthy vs. metabolic diseases); (vi) for enrollment sites (e.g. single centre vs. multi-centres).
Sensitivity analyses
The following sensitivity analyses will be performed: (i) by excluding studies with unpublished literature; (ii) by excluding studies with small sample sized trials (sample size<50); and (iii) by excluding studies with high bias based on ‘Risk of Bias’ assessment.

attributes.title: Meta-analysis DOAC vs LMWH in cancer patients

q1.value: Direct oral anticoagulants versus low-molecular-weight heparins for the treatment of cancer-associated venous thromboembolism: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q3.value: In this systematic review meta-analysis we seek to obtain summary estimates of the safety and efficacy of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) and low-molecular weight heparins (LMWH) for the treatment of venous thromboembolism in cancer patients by aggregating results of all randomized controlled trials.

q4.value: DOACs are associated with a numerically higher risk of major bleeding, but lower risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Meta-analysis of all randomized trials comparing DOACs and LMWH for the treatment of cancer associated venous thromboembolism.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A comprehensive search will be performed in MEDLINE, Embase, and the Cochrane central register of controlled trials, without restrictions for year of publication or language, to identify all randomized controlled trials that compared DOACs and LMWH for the treatment of VTE in cancer patients. Additionally, a manual search will be performed to identify relevant abstracts presented at the last editions of relevant conferences. Two reviewers will independently screen records, abstracts, and extract data in standardized data collection forms.

q13.value: We expect to identify at least four relevant studies.

question.value: The treatment arms are those treated with DOACs and those with LMWH.

The primary safety outcome is major bleeding, defined as per the ISTH criteria. The primary efficacy outcome is recurrent VTE, defined as symptomatic or incidental new deep-vein thrombosis (DVT) of upper or lower extremities, symptomatic pulmonary embolism (PE), incidental PE involving segmental or more proximal pulmonary arteries, or fatal PE or unexplained death for which PE cannot be ruled out as the cause. Splanchnic vein thrombosis, cerebral vein thrombosis and upper extremity DVT will be excluded from the primary efficacy outcome . Other safety outcomes are all-cause mortality and clinically relevant non-major bleeding (CRNMB), which is defined as per the ISTH criteria.

The primary effect measure will be the risk ratio comparing both anticoagulant treatment arms for all study outcomes. The secondary  effect measures will be the absolute risk, and absolute risk reduction. The absolute risk in the DOAC arm will be calculated from the observed absolute risk with LMWH and the pooled relative risks between the anticoagulant treatment arms. 
Logit transformation and inverse variance weighting will be  used to calculate summary estimates in a Knapp-Hartung random-effects model.Between-study heterogeneity will be assessed by calculating tau-squared (τ2) using restricted maximum likelihood estimations. 
The primary analysis will be restricted to studies that had included patients with acute symptomatic or incidentally detected lower-extremity DVT involving the popliteal, femoral, or iliac vein or the inferior vena cava, acute symptomatic PE, incidentally detected PE involving segmental or more proximal pulmonary arteries, or (suspected) fatal PE as index event. A secondary analysis will include studies that enrolled patients with any type of VTE index event other than superficial, or catheter-related VTE. A separate analysis will be performed for the subgroups of patients with gastrointestinal cancer, urogenital cancer, and for patients with an incidental  VTE index event. Publication bias will be explored with a funnel plot.

question2a.value: The group assigned to the participant (Powerful or control) (between participants)

question3b.value:
in exploratory analysis we will check if the following act as control variables:
a.	Gender (male, female, other, prefer not to say)
b.	Age (open ended, in years)
c.	Experience as a supervisor (1- currently a supervisor, 2 - was a supervisor, 3 - never)

question10b.value: All participants will be given a survey to complete. Control and Powerful participants will be paired up and given access to one survey form on Unipark. Access will first be granted to control members, and then powerful members. Their data will be separated for analysis. On the first page of the experiment there will be a release form explaining that they consent to take part in an experiment focused on “socialization patterns” and that they understand they may remain anonymous. The next page will contain the questionnaires themselves. The participant will be given their role. There will be a second section where participants will be asked to fill out an additional questionnaire to measure whether sense of power is felt. Similar to P.K Smith et al.’s 2008 paper, this will consist of 20 of 9-point scales with a trait on each side. The trait pairs will include 7 designated to indicate a sense of power, as well as 13 unrelated filler pairs to throw off suspicion and check that participants are paying attention. After this manipulation check, both groups will be asked to estimate the time needed to accomplish a task. The task is a writing assignment for a social media posting. The experiment will be conducted in two runs. As the survey will be made available on a public forum, it is not expected the first group will have any difference to the second which should affect the answers provided. The first run will only allow participants into the control group. Control group members will be given a modified version of the writing task to complete, and informed that writing this will enable them to potentially receive a bonus. After all control responses have been collected, the next group surveyed will be the powerful group. Powerful group participants will be asked to assess results from members of the control group. Members of this second group will be given up to $1 USD to allocate as a bonus to the control group participant whose submitted work they are evaluating. They will be assured that the scores will be kept anonymous. Finally, both groups will be asked for demographic data. The final section contains control variables to test that for example, age and gender are not affecting the outcomes. They will appear as: Gender: Male/Female/Other/Prefer not to say, Age, and experience as a supervisor. After completing the survey, the participant will enter a code provided to them into the Mechanical Turk site. After the survey is reviewed, all participants will be compensated for the work completed ($1, which amounts to .90 Euros based on conversion rate on the 4th of March 2020)  as well as any additional bonus which has been awarded to them.

question4b.value: Adult workers on Mechanical Turk will be offered the chance to take the survey for financial compensation

question5b.value: There will be two categories of 86 participants each. In total this should lead to 171~ participants

question6b.value: After testing, the full survey will be run once with the powerful group and control group  (Up to 171 participants). This number of participants was chosen based on calculations from the g*power program, evaluating a T-test with a effect size of .21, based on Weick and Guinote 2010 pg 602.

question7b.value: When we reach 171 total responses, then we will check if some surveys ought to be excluded based on exclusion rules. If we are left with less than the desired number of completed surveys, we will repeat this procedure until we reach atleast 171.

e.	Not including or falsifying Mturk worker ID

The next page will contain the questionnaires themselves. The participant will be given their role. There will be a second section where participants will be asked to fill out an additional questionnaire to measure whether sense of power is felt. Similar to P.K Smith et al.’s 2008 paper, this will consist of 20 of 9-point scales with a trait on each side. The trait pairs will include 7 designated to indicate a sense of power, as well as 13 unrelated filler pairs to throw off suspicion and check that participants are paying attention. After this manipulation check, both groups will be asked to estimate the time needed to accomplish a task. The task is a writing assignment for a social media posting. The experiment will be conducted in two runs. As the survey will be made available on a public forum, it is not expected the first group will have any difference to the second which should affect the answers provided. The first run will only allow participants into the control group. Control group members will be given a modified version of the writing task to complete, and informed that writing this will enable them to potentially receive a bonus. After all control responses have been collected, the next group surveyed will be the powerful group. Powerful group participants will be asked to assess results from members of the control group. Members of this second group will be given up to $1 USD to allocate as a bonus to the control group participant whose submitted work they are evaluating. They will be assured that the scores will be kept anonymous. Finally, both groups will be asked for demographic data. The final section contains control variables to test that for example, age and gender are not affecting the outcomes. They will appear as: Gender: Male/Female/Other/Prefer not to say, Age, and experience as a supervisor. After completing the survey, the participant will enter a code provided to them into the Mechanical Turk site. After the survey is reviewed, all participants will be compensated for the work completed ($1, which amounts to .90 Euros based on conversion rate on the 4th of March 2020)  as well as any additional bonus which has been awarded to them.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Power: average of the 7 items used as a manipulation check in the survey
Task time: Time estimated by each participant
Group assigned
Null Hypothesis, Linear Regression, and Correlation

Control variables: gender, age, experience
Gender: 2 factor anova analysis with power group, gender, power group x gender
Age: linear regression of power group and age, power group x age
Experience: anova analysis with power group, experience, power group x experience
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Adult workers on Mechanical Turk will be offered the chance to take the survey for financial compensation
There will be two categories of 86 participants each. In total this should lead to 171~ participants

After testing, the full survey will be run once with the powerful group and control group  (Up to 171 participants). This number of participants was chosen based on calculations from the g*power program, evaluating a T-test with a effect size of .21, based on Weick and Guinote 2010 pg 602.

When we reach 171 total responses, then we will check if some surveys ought to be excluded based on exclusion rules. If we are left with less than the desired number of completed surveys, we will repeat this procedure until we reach atleast 171.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a.	Missing or incomplete responses
b.	failing check-tests or suspicion probes
c.	Not taking the writing portion seriously, for example “first blah second blahblah, third blah” or “Bippidi bobbidi boo”
d.	Withdrawal of consent
e.	Not including or falsifying Mturk worker ID

attributes.title: Reading time regularity
attributes.description:
Investigating natural text reading as complex, dynamical process

How can we quantify the coupling between a text and reading performance? The hypothesis of reading time regularity (RTR) states that the degree of regularity in measures of the reading process (e.g., reading times or eye movements) is informative about reading fluency and comprehension. Hence, RTR captures the extent to which relevant linguistic information of a text controls its perceptual-cognitive processing during reading. Our project aims at investigating this hypothesis.

q1.value: Disentangling sources of text comprehension using confirmatory factor analysis

q3.value:
Many theories of discourse processing assume that understanding a text requires generating a mental model of the text (e.g., Verhoeven & Perfetti, 2008). As a first step, a reader has to identify the basic units of a text, namely its words, and then words must be integrated into a coherent structure. To achieve this, a text can be divided into different levels of informational structure, which in turn require different processing  mechanisms. As reading progresses, simply adding up propositions of successive sentences would depict the micro level, whereas only propositions of more global relevance are thought to build the macro level of a text. Moreover, information is combined with a reader's world knowledge, leading to inferences that might exceed the literal meaning of a text (Kintsch & van Dijk, 1978, O’Brien & Cook, 2015, Verhoeven & Perfetti, 2008). 
The aim of the current study is to test whether or how these three different levels (micro structure, macro structure, inferences) contribute to text comprehension.
For this purpose, three short stories of comparable length and linguistic characteristics were selected. For each of the three stories a total of 16 w-questions and 60 yes/no-statements were constructed with each 10 w-questions and 40 statements referring to micro level information, while the remaining items are based on inferences. Subjects are asked to freely answer the w-questions and to judge the statements as right or wrong. Since the macro level only contains the weighed propositions (i.e., the main contents) of a text, participants were also instructed to write short summaries. The study is implemented as an online survey, and each participant is randomly assigned a text. Different texts were used in order to ensure a minimum of generalisation of the results across, at least, a certain range of texts.

q4.value:
By means of confirmatory factor analysis, different models of text comprehension will be modelled and compared. On this basis, we intend to deduce whether text comprehension can be considered a one-dimensional or multi-dimensional construct.
In additional exploratory analyses, we will to test how well different comprehension models predict subjects' liking and global interest ratings, as well as their text reading times. 

Our baseline model will be a uni-factor model,  with only a single comprehension factor.
Competing models will be (A.) a 3-factor model, containing factors loading on items that are supposed to capture the micro and macro level of comprehension, as well as inferences, and (B.) the model described in (A.), but with a second-order factor capturing general comprehension based on these three lower-order factors.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants were randomly assigned to one of three texts. Different text comprehension items together with text reading times and subjective ratings of liking and global interest were assessed.

q9.value: Participants were randomly assigned to one of three texts. Additionally, the order of presentation of the comprehension items was randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data collection is ongoing. Hence, we have not inspected any parts of the data yet.

question.value: Participants must be at least 18 years old and native speakers of German. They are recruited via flyers (handed out in local pedestrian zones, cafés, cinemas, book stores and libraries), adverts (institute's homepage, facebook) or emails (in-house database, open email lists). Participants can freely decide to take part in a lottery to win book vouchers of 10€ with odds of one in five.

q13.value: Following recommendations for conducting factor analysis (Mundfrom, et al., 2005, Wolf, et al., 2013), we are aiming for 75 to 120 valid data sets per text. Beyond that, there is no fixed upper limit for sample size. Data collection is scheduled from December 15, 2019 until March 8, 2020.

q14.value: Our sampling plan is in line with recommendations for conducting factor analysis proposed by Mundfrom and colleagues (2005) or Wolf and colleagues (2013) for models with up to 3 first-order factors.

question.value: The study is an observational study. Thus, no variables were manipulated. Each participant is randomly assigned to one of three short stories which, however, were selected to be of similar difficulty. The aim here was so ensure generalisation of our results over at least a certain range of texts.

For each participant, we are collecting:
  – 60 yes/no comprehension statements (40 based on micro structure, 20 on inferences),
  – 16 w-questions (10 based on micro structure, 6 on inferences),
  – 1 summary;
  – 3 liking ratings & 1 global interest rating (7-point-scale);
  – reading time (in seconds)

Moreover, we collect standard demographic information and affective and emotion-related ratings that are not part of the present study or analysis, and that also bear no theoretical relationship to the main constructs of interest (i.e., the different levels of comprehension).
We will conduct factor analysis on our items (see hypothesis).

As a fist step, we will conduct an item analysis to filter out items with bad psychometric properties (based on inspection of individual and joint distributions of items). We will then use confirmatory factor analysis to model the different hypotheses (see above). We will furthermore inspect modification indices to delete items that do not fit well into the overall model solutions. As a last step, model comparison between those models will be performed (using Chi-square difference tests and information criteria).

q21.value:
To compare models: (bayesian) information criteria (rank order) and Chi-square differences (p < .05).

To assess individual model fit: specific model fit indices (RMSEA < .08, CFT < .95, TFL < .95, SRMR < .1).

q23.value: Data sets with missing values will be discarded.

q24.value: We will test, how well different comprehension models predict subjetcs' liking and global interest ratings. Furthermore, we will test, how well different comprehension models predict subjetcs' reading times.

q3.value:
Recovering a three-dimensional shape of an object from a two-dimensional retinal image is an ill-posed problem in vision science. The shape of the retinal image changes depending on the object’s shape, distance, and orientation. Despite this difficulty, the visual system can achieve shape constancy. The perceived shape of the object stays constant despite change of the object’s retinal image. Previous studies have shown that perpendicularity of contours in a retinal image is processed with a great efficiency by the human visual system.
Perpendicularity also plays a crucial role in the shape perception. The human visual system is biased to see perpendicular angles (Perkins, 1976). The visual system uses perpendicularity as a priori constraints for perceiving a shape of an object. Consider Ames room. The distorted shape of the room is perceived as a regular shape with perpendicular corners. However, the process of perceiving a 3-D shape with this perpendicularity constraint is not well understood.
In this project, we will conduct an experiment to test performance of the human visual system to perceive a perpendicular corner of contours in stereo. We expect that the visual system can reliably process perpendicularity.

q4.value:
This is an exploratory study.
It is possible that perpendicularity can either enhance or suppress human performance. If the performance is enhanced, it can be interpreted that the visual system is sensitive to perpendicularity. If the performance is suppressed, it can be interpreted that perception of a corner is biased toward being perpendicular (Perkins, 1976) and the visual system becomes insensitive to small difference from a perpendicular corner.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The method of signal detection is used. Each subject runs 1 session for each type of the contours (3 sessions in total) in a randomized order.
The number of trials in each session is 200.

q9.value: An order of sessions is randomized for each subject. Sequence of trials in each session is also randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data from three participants (MD, TS, MF) was already collected.

question.value:
Stimuli will be displayed on 120Hz 24-inch LCD monitor (BenQ Zowie XL2411) in a dark room. The subjects view the display binocularly with a pair of stereo 3D glasses from a distance of 100cm. Resolution of the screen is 1920 × 1080 pixels and its size is 53.1 × 29.8 cm. The head of observer is fixed by using a chinrest. A black panel (57 × 50 cm) with a circular aperture (29 cm in diameter) is placed on the screen.
A trial starts with a fixation point at the center of the screen. An observer presses a mouse button and two intervals of visual stimuli are shown. Duration of each interval is 500 ms. A response screen with two choices will be shown after the second interval. The task for observer is to judge which of two junctions was more perpendicular (not distorted). A subject will choose the answer using the mouse. An audio feedback about the accuracy of the response was given when the observer makes an error.

q13.value: We will have 6 subjects recruited from the National research university Higher school of Economics.

q14.value: Based on past psychophysical studies on analogous topics (e.g. Koshmanova & Sawada, 2019), 6 is sufficiently large.

question.value:
Perception of 3 types of perpendicular corners is tested in separate sessions. The corner is composed of 2 white and 1 red contours. Condition-1: all the contours form a perfectly rectangular corner. Condition-2: the red contour forms perpendicular angles with the white contours but an angle between the white contours is 45°. Condition-3: the white contours form a perpendicular angle but their normal forms an angle of 45° with the red contour. 
In each trial, two stereo pairs of images of the corners are shown sequentially with random orientations. One of the corners is distorted by disorienting contours of the corner for 20° in the depth direction. In Conditions-1 and -2, the red contour is disoriented. In Condition-3, one of the white contours is disoriented. The task for observer is to choose which corner is not distorted.
Numbers of correct responses when the 1st or 2nd corner is distorted.
From these two numbers of correct responses, detectability measure dʹ is estimated.

Results of the experiment will be analysed using 1-way repeated measure ANOVA within-subject design. A post-hoc test (Tukey) will be conducted to compare different configurations if the configuration effect is observed.

q20.value: Any additional transformation will not be applied to the data of the experiment.

q21.value: A 5% inference criteria will be used for 1-way repeated measure ANOVA.

q22.value: No data will be excluded as long as the participant will complete all trials.

q23.value: Data will be excluded if the participant did not complete the experiments.
